questions.text: Spur cells are seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Spur cells are irregularly distorted red blood cells containing several irregularly distributed thorn-like projections.
  • Cells with these morphological abnormalities are also called acanthocytes.
  • They are seen in splenectomised patients and patients with liver disease.

Incorrect options:

Option A, B, D: Spur cells are not a histological finding in these conditions.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with Fatigue, weakness, and exertional dyspnea for 5 months. Hb is 8.9 g/dl, MCV is 78 fl. Serum iron and ferritin are raised, and Bone marrow biopsy confirms the presence of sideroblasts. Which of the following is used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical history and lab findings are suggestive of Acquired Sideroblastic anaemia, probably caused by chronic alcoholism.
  • Sideroblastic anaemia may be hereditary or acquired.
  • Causes of acquired sideroblastic anaemia are
    • Excessive alcohol use
    • Vitamin B6 or copper deficiency
    • Lead poisoning or zinc overdose
    • Cancer or myelodysplastic syndrome
    • Certain medications, such as antibiotics, chemotherapeutics, and chelators
  • Management includes:
    • Remove triggers (alcohol, lead, zinc toxicity).
    • Pyridoxine (B6) supplementation
    • Iron chelation

Incorrect options:

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) (Option A) is essential for energy metabolism (Krebs cycle, pentose phosphate pathway) and nerve function. Deficiency leads to beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Iron (Option B): Patient is already in an iron overload. So administering iron is contraindicated.

Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) (Option D) is required for collagen synthesis, and deficiency causes Scurvy.

questions.text: A patient with a mediastinal mass was diagnosed with red cell aplasia. What is the most probable cause of aplasia?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Pure red cell aplasia can either be inherited or acquired.

  1. Congenital PRCA: Diamond-Blackfan syndrome
  2. Acquired PRCA:
    1. Autoimmune/Collagen disorders - systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease.
    2. Leukemias
    3. Lymphoproliferative disorders: CLL, LGL
    4. ABO-incompatible stem cell transplant
    5. Solid tumours: Thymoma
    6. Virus
      1. Parvovirus B19 (most common) - can lead to transient aplastic crises
      2. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
      3. T-cell leukaemia-lymphoma virus, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
      4. Hepatitis A, B, C, and E
      5. Cytomegalovirus
    7. Bacterial infections - group C streptococcus, tuberculosis, bacterial sepsis
    8. Drugs - recombinant erythropoietin (rhEPO) is the most common.

Incorrect Options:

Bronchogenic Ca (Option A) is very rarely associated with PRCA.

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (Option B) may present with a Mediastinal mass and be associated with PRCA, but rarely so.

questions.solution: Explanation:

questions.text: 14-month-old with repeated blood transfusion history with Hb 6 g/dl and last 3 transfusions given in 9 months. What is the investigation for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Smear shows marked Anisopoikilocytosis with nucleated RBC, suggestive of Thalassemia major.

Diagnosis can be made on Hb HPLC; however can be confirmed on beta globin gene sequencing with more reliability, considering the age of the patient and is considered the Investigation of choice (Option A, C, D ruled out).

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy Fatigability and Pallor, Hyperpigmented Knuckles, and white nails, as shown in the picture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hyperpigmented knuckles are characteristically seen in Vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • B12 deficiency leads to Megaloblastic anaemia
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Inadequate synthesis of thymidine and defective DNA replication.
    • Results in enlarged abnormal hematopoietic precursors (megaloblasts), ineffective hematopoiesis, macrocytic anaemia, and (in most cases) pancytopenia
  • B12 deficiency is also associated with neurologic damage, particularly in the posterior and lateral tracts of the spinal cord

Incorrect Options:

Aplastic anaemia (Option A) usually presents with more severe symptoms of Pancytopenia, like recurrent infections, bleeding, etc.

IDA (Option C) is not usually associated with Hyperpigmented knuckles

choices.text: Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy caused rapid use of B12 stores aggravating symptoms

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came with complaints of easy fatigability, exertion dyspnea and weight loss. She also complains of frequent falls. Physical Examination revealed there was a bilateral decrease in vibration sense. Her Hb levels were 8.2 g/dL. She was treated with folate. Her anaemia improved, but neurological symptoms worsened. Which of the following is the most probable reason for her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Folate therapy in case of deficiency leads to rapid use of B12 stores, which leads to worsening of existing neurological deficits.
  • B12 plays a Major role in providing cofactors that are required to form Myelin, required for the production of methionine (precursor for S-adenosyl methionine), which is required for methylation reactions.
  • Demyelination occurs from vitamin B12 deficiency. Neurological problems occur in most people who are deficient in vitamin B12.
  • Folic acid can usually correct the anaemia. Thus it could mask the underlying disease and allow the development or progression of neurological deterioration if diagnosis depended on the presence of anaemic symptoms.

Incorrect options:

Folate not absorbed (Option A): In this case, Folate was absorbed ,and the anaemia was thus corrected.

Pyridoxine(vitamin B6) deficiency (Option B) usually presents with burning sensation, parasthesia, confusion, seizures but not usually associated with anaemi and loss of sensation.

Deficiency of Folate reductase in CNS (Option C) usually presents with Megaloblastic anaemia, Hyperhomocysteinemia and symptoms like fatigue, Depression and Cognitive decline.

questions.text:
Match the following :

Select the correct answer using the code below:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Howell-Jolly bodies are red cell inclusions which are residual nuclear fragments. They may be seen in hemolysis, megaloblastic anaemia, or post-splenectomy.
  • Dohle bodies are seen in inflammatory states and are composed of agglutinated rough endoplasmic reticulum containing RNA in neutrophils.
  • Flame cells are Ig inclusion-containing plasma cells seen in multiple myeloma.
  • Auer rods are abnormally elongated azurophilic granules seen in myeloblasts in AML patients.

questions.solution: Explanation:

choices.text: Ask the patient his name → ®Verify from file → Label the sample at bedside → Collect blood
Look at the file → Collect sample → Label the sample at bedside
Prelabel the sample vials → Check the file for patient details → Collect sample
Collect sample → Confirm name from file → Label the sample vial

questions.text: What should be the sequence of events during collection of blood sample?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

WHO guidelines on drawing blood: best practices in phlebotomy

The following is the recommended sequence of events during the collection of a blood sample:

  1. Select the site: Blood is usually collected from veins, capillaries, and arteries. Venous blood is collected from the antecubital vein most commonly. Blood is also collected from the veins ofthe arms, dorsum of the hands. The long cephalic vein is also used where the non-availability of the former veins. The infant's femoral vein is used for the collection of blood.
  2. Prepare the patient: Explain the procedure to the patient and obtain consent. Position the patient comfortably and ensure that the patient is relaxed.
  3. Prepare the equipment: Ensure that all the equipment is ready and within reach. The equipment includes a tourniquet, alcohol swabs, needles, tubes, and a tray.
  4. Apply the tourniquet: Apply the tourniquet to the upper arm and ask the patient to make a fist.
  5. Clean the site: Clean the site with an alcohol swab and allow it to dry.
  6. Insert the needle: Insert the needle into the vein at a 15-30 degree angle with the bevel up. Once the needle is in the vein, release the tourniquet.
  7. Collect the blood: Collect the required amount of blood into the appropriate tubes. Invert the tubes gently to mix the sample well. Do not shake vigorously as this may lead to hemolysis of the blood sample.
  8. Remove the needle: Once the required amount of blood has been collected, remove the needle from the vein and apply pressure to the site with a cotton ball or gauze.
  9. Dispose of the equipment: Dispose of the equipment in the appropriate manner.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of chronic fatigue and pallor. Her CBC reveals Hb: 9.8 g/dL, MCV: 78 fL, RDW: 18.5%. Her peripheral blood smear reveals variation in RBC size. Which of the following RBC abnormalities does the elevated RDW most directly reflect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The RDW is an index of the variation in cell size and volume within the red cell population(Option A, C, D ruled out).

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came to OPD 1 year after postpartum. She was treated for iron deficiency anaemia during pregnancy. Now she is pal,e and her Hb was 5% and reticulocyte count was 9%. Her corrected retic count is:
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Reticulocyte Count has Two Corrections

  • Correction for the degree of anaemia (Absolute reticulocyte count) and Correction for the prolonged duration of stay of reticulocyte in peripheral smear.
  • Corrected reticulocyte count % = Reticulocyte Count X Hematocrit / 45 , where Hematocrit = Hb X 3
  • In this case, Corrected reticulocyte count % = 9 x 15/45 = 3

questions.text: Decreased ESR is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A decreased Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) can be caused by several factors. Here are some of the common causes:

  1. Polycythemia Vera:This is a condition characterised by an increased number of red blood cells
  2. Sickle Cell Disease:This is a genetic disorder that affects the shape and functionality of the red blood cells
  3. Hyperviscosity Syndrome:This is a group of symptoms triggered by an increase in the viscosity of the blood
  4. Hereditary Spherocytosis:This is a condition that leads to an abnormality in the red blood cell membrane, causing the cells to take on a spherical shape
  5. Abetalipoproteinemia and Acanthocytosis:These are rare inherited disorders affecting fat absorption and red blood cell shape

Options B, C , and D were ruled out.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented in December with chronic fatigue and cyanosis with bluish lips and arthralgia. Peripheral blood film is shown below. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given Peripheral smear shows RBC agglutination with Normocytic Normochromic RBCs. The history is suggestive of agglutination occurring in the month of December, that is cold-induced-Cold Agglutinin Type.
  • History of Chronic fatigue and cyanosis is suggestive of anemia.
  • This form of immunohemolytic anemia is caused by IgM antibodies that bind red cells avidly at low temperatures (0°-4°C).

Incorrect options:

Warm AIHA (Option B):

  • Characterised by IgG-mediated destruction of RBCs at body temperature (37°C).
  • IgG-mediated reactions, leading to mostly Extravascular hemolysis.

Hemoglobinopathies (Option C), like SCD, HbC, HbE, Thalassemias, do not usually present with RBC agglutination.

G6PD deficiency (Option D):

  • X-linked recessive disorder causing hemolytic anaemia due to impaired protection of RBCs against oxidative stress.
  • Peripheral smear shows Heinz bodies, Bite cells.

questions.text: A 6-year-old patient with anemia on electrophoresis, shows HbF 90%, Hb A2 3%. Which of the following will be seen on peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history and HPLC findings are suggestive of Thalassemia major, which will have severe Anisopoikilocytosis (slide C), Nucleated RBC (slide B) and Howell-Jolly bodies (slide A)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman from Southeast Asia presents to her obstetrician for routine prenatal care. She reports fatigue and mild pallor but no other symptoms. Her CBC shows: Hb 10.2 g/dL, MCV 68 fL, MCH 22 pg and Peripheral smear shows Microcytic, hypochromic RBCs with target cells. The physician suspects thalassemia trait and orders a screening test. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial screening test for thalassemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Screening tests for Thalassemia trait: NESTROFT (Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility Test) assesses osmotic fragility of red cells at a single concentration of buffered saline (0.36% in a single tube)

Incorrect options:

The alkali denaturation test(Option A) is used to distinguish between fetal and maternal blood.

Kleihauer-Betke test(Option B) is a blood test used to detect and quantify fetal red blood cells in maternal circulation, typically after a potential fetomaternal haemorrhage.

Hb electrophoresis(Option C) is not used as a screening test but as a confirmatory test for definitive diagnosis.

choices.text: TIBC increased, Ferritin increased, Transferrin saturation increased, Serum transferrin receptors increased
TIBC reduced, Ferritin reduced, Transferrin saturation reduced, Serum transferrin receptors decreased
TIBC increased, Ferritin reduced, Transferrin saturation reduced, Serum transferrin receptors decreased
TIBC increased, Ferritin reduced, Transferrin saturation reduced, Serum transferrin receptors increased

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator to assess iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In iron deficiency anaemia, TIBC (Total iron-binding capacity) is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.
  • The diagnosis of IDA ultimately rests on laboratory studies
  • Serum Fe and ferritin are low, and the total plasma Fe binding capacity is high. Low serum Fe with increased Fe binding capacity results in a reduction of transferring saturation to below 15%.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits the function of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Hepcidin is a regulator of iron metabolism.
  • Hepcidin inhibits iron transport by binding to the iron export channel ferroportin, which is located on the basolateral surface of gut enterocytes and the plasma membrane of reticuloendothelial cells (macrophages).

Regulation of Iron Absorption:

Incorrect options:

DMT1 protein (Option A), also known as Nramp2, SLC11A2, and DCT1, conducts iron transport at two distinct compartments of the cell:

  • It facilitates iron uptake at the apical cell membrane, for instance, in duodenal enterocytes.
  • It transports iron across erythroid precursors in the bone marrow.

Hephaestin(Option B) is a protein involved in iron transport, specifically facilitating the movement of iron from intestinal cells into the bloodstream.

Cerruloplasmin(Option C) is a copper-containing glycoprotein (α-globulin) synthesised in the liver, playing key roles in:

  • Copper transport & homeostasis (binds 90% of plasma copper).
  • Iron metabolism (ferroxidase activity).
  • Antioxidant defence (scavenges free radicals).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic fatigue, pallor, and frequent dizziness presents to her primary care physician. The physician suspects iron deficiency anaemia and orders further tests to evaluate iron metabolism. During the workup, the physician reviews the key proteins involved in iron metabolism. Which of the following proteins is NOT directly involved in iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Transthyretin (TTR), also called Prealbumin, is a transport protein synthesised primarily in the liver and, to a lesser extent, in the choroid plexus and retina.
  • Functions:
    • Thyroid hormone transport
    • Retinol transport

Incorrect options:

Hepcidin(Option A) is a regulator of iron metabolism. It controls systemic iron balance by:

  • Inhibiting iron absorption in duodenal enterocytes.
  • Blocking iron release from macrophages (recycling old RBCs).
  • Regulating placental iron transfer during pregnancy.

g pregnancy.

Ferroportin(Option B) is an iron export channel that is located on the basolateral surface of gut enterocytes and the plasma membrane of macrophages.

Cerruloplasmin(Option D) is a copper-containing glycoprotein (α-globulin) synthesised in the liver, playing key roles in:

  • Copper transport & homeostasis (binds 90% of plasma copper).
  • Iron metabolism (ferroxidase activity).
  • Antioxidant defence (scavenges free radicals).

questions.text: Bone marrow failure with neutropenia and exocrine pancreatic deficiency is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Shwachman-Diamond syndrome (SDS) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterised by exocrine pancreatic insufficiency and persistent or intermittent neutropenia and an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Hematologic problems also can include anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and pancytopenia

Incorrect options:

Fanconi anaemia (Option A) is an autosomal recessive disorder that may be caused by mutations in more than a dozen different genes, each encoding a protein that participates in a pathway that repairs DNA cross-links through homologous recombination. It is characterised by developmental abnormalities (short stature, skeletal abnormalities), hypersensitivity to chemotherapeutic agents that cross-link DNA, and increased risk of bone marrow failure (aplasia) and leukaemia.

Dyskeratosis congenita (Option B)is a rare, inherited bone marrow failure syndrome caused by defects in telomere maintenance, leading to premature ageing and multi-organ dysfunction

Diamond-Blackfan Anaemia (Option C) refers to Inherited Forms of Red cell Aplastic anaemia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with hereditary spherocytosis presents to the pediatric haematology clinic with sudden onset of fatigue, pallor, and jaundice. His parents report he had a mild fever and rash one week prior. The haematologist suspectsa transient aplastic crisis (TAC) secondary to an infection. Parvovirus B19, the most common cause of TAC, preferentially targets which of the following bone marrow cell types?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A special form of red cell aplasia occurs in individuals infected with parvovirus B19, which preferentially infects and destroys Erythroid progenitors.
  • Normal individuals clear parvovirus infections within 1 to 2 weeks; as a result, the aplasia is transient and clinically unimportant.
  • However, in persons with moderate to severe hemolytic anaemias, even a brief cessation of erythropoiesis results in rapid worsening of the anaemia, producing an aplastic crisis.
